Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator proposes to continue his project on several topics in number theory, automorphic forms and arithmetic geometry. With various collaborators, the PI will investigate the Gan-Gross-Prasad periods, the generalized Waldspurger formula for unitary groups conjectured by Ichino--Ikeda and N. Harris, as well as the representation theoretical formulation of Gross--Zagier formula to higher dimensional Shimura varieties by S. Zhang. The PI will also pursue the arithmetic fundamental lemma, a relevant conjectural identity between a certain orbital integral and a certain intersection number on Rapoport--Zink space.

This research concerns a special type of mathematical object defined by algebraic equations, known as algebraic cycles, which contain important information about geometry and arithmetic. They have applications to the arithmetic of elliptic curves, particularly the Birch--Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture, one of the seven Millennium Prize Problems of the Clay Mathematics Institute. The study of elliptic curve is crucial in many areas such as cryptography and information security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Solving Diophantine equations, i.e., solving algebraic equations in whole numbers or rational numbers, is one of the oldest traditions in mathematics. For instance, the "Archimedes’ cattle problem” around the year of 250 BC, corresponds to a special case of the so-called Pell equation $x^2-dy^2=1$ where $d$ is a natural number. A more recent example is depicted by the Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture, one of the Millennium problems, which offers deep insight into the solutions in rational numbers to cubic equations in two variables of the form $y^2=x^3+ax+b$ where $a,b$ are rational numbers. 

The geometric point of view is helpful to Diophantine questions, i.e., one studies the geometric shape defined by algebraic equations, called an "algebraic variety" (e.g.,  an "elliptic curve" in Birch and Swinnerton—Dyer conjecture). Then solving Diophantine equations amounts to finding points (i.e., zero dimensional objects) with coordinates in rational numbers lying on an algebraic variety.  One of the modern generalizations of solving Diophantine equations asks how to characterize the existence of higher dimensional objects (still defined by algebraic equations with rational coefficients), called "algebraic cycles", lying on an algebraic variety. 

The Hodge conjecture, another Millennium problem, and the Tate conjecture characterize the existence of algebraic cycles modulo an equivalence relation called ``cohomological equivalence".  The cohomological equivalence is very coarse and it is natural to consider finer equivalence relations. One of the most frequently used is the rational equivalence  and this leads us to the concept of the Chow group of an algebraic variety. Besides the aforementioned conjectures of Hodge and Tate on algebraic cycles modulo cohomological equivalence,  a series of conjectures of Beilinson, Bloch, and Bloch--Kato predict a deep connection between the Chow group (an invariant defined by algebraic means) and the L-function (an invariant defined by complex analysis) of an algebraic variety. These conjectures are the counterparts to general algebraic varieties of the Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture to elliptic curves.

The PI and his collaborators investigated L-functions and algebraic cycles on Shimura varieties, a class of algebraic varieties that are central in the study of Langlands program, especially in the construction of Galois representations associated to automorphic representations. 

To describe the results and the methods, we recall the classical result that one can use special values of trigonometric functions to construct ``almost all" solutions to the Pell equation $x^2-dy^2=1$. Here ``almost all" can be measured quantitatively in terms of the class number of the real quadric field $Q[\sqrt{d}]$ when $d$ does not have any square factor (recall that the class number is essentially the number of binary quadratic forms with discriminant $d$ or $4d$, up to ``change of variables"). This is the content of the Dirichlet class number formula for real quadratic fields. We also notice that a dichotomy appears here: when $d<0$, it is a trivial question to solve the equation $x^2-dy^2=1$ in whole numbers, but the Dirichlet class number formula yields nontrivial information, i.e., a closed formula of the class number of the imaginary quadratic field $Q[\sqrt{d}]$.

Just as  the trigonometric functions can be used to solve the Pell equation, modular functions can be used to construct rational points on elliptic curves, called Heegner points. Gross--Zagier formula provides a criterion when the Heegner points are nontrivial in terms of the L-function of an elliptic curve. This is the counterpart of the class number formula for the real quadratic field. Moreover, a dichotomy also appears: the formula of Waldspurger is the counterpart of the class number formula for imaginary quadratic fields. Thanks also to the work of Kolyvagin, Heegner points are used to prove many cases of Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture. In fact, the PI and his collaborators proved that, when ordered by heights, about two thirds of elliptic curves over the rational numbers satisfy the Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture.  One of the key ingredients is the PI's proof of the Kolyvagin conjecture on non-vanishing of Heegner points Euler system. 

Heegner points live over one dimensional Shimura varieties. In the case of higher dimensional Shimura varieties, one of the generalizations of the above construction is via the arithmetic Gan--Gross--Prasad conjecture. The PI and collaborators have been using the tool of Jacquet--Rallis relative trace formulae to attack this conjecture for unitary Shimura varieties. The major advance is the discovery of a conjectural arithmetic fundamental lemma, as well as ``an arithmetic transfer conjecture" for Rapoport--Zink spaces attached to a ramified quadratic extension of p-adic fields. The first nontrivial cases of these conjectures are proved.   

In the case of function fields, the PI and his collaborator proved a higher Gross--Zagier formula, relating the higher order derivative of L-functions to "Heegner--Drinfeld cycles" on the moduli space of Shtukas on $GL(2)$. This was not among the initial proposed projects. However, it is a discovery out of the initially proposed methods of relative trace formulae.
